description.narrative: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: The percentage of innovative solutions and projects advancing digitalization in the Country Office increases by supporting the designing and formulation of projects specific on innovation.

comment.narrative: Tanzania envisions a strong and competitive economy that will provide improved socio-economic opportunities, public sector performance and sustainable environmental management. Through its National Vision 2025 plan, the country aims at transferring its least developed economy into a middle-income modern economy. The vision is based on the principle of sustainable development, where present generations will be able to derive benefits to rational use of natural resources of the country, without compromising the needs of future generations. On the other hand, The Tanzania 1996 Science and Technology policy (currently under revision) acknowledges science, technology and innovation as key tools for fostering industrial development and eventually developing modern economy. Tanzania’s STI development strategies are in line with the United Nations’ sustainable development goal nine (9) which calls for Investment in infrastructure and innovation as crucial drivers of economic growth and development. Moreover, In the previous 2015 elections in Tanzania that gave power to the 5th phase of Government under H.E John Pombe Magufuli, the main agenda from the onset was that the government will promote industrial development in order to create jobs for millions of young people in Tanzania and to build a modern economy.

- Enhanced communications and local engagement by supporting and organising innovation events, forming strategic partnerships with various government and private institutions, supporting Tanzanias innovation week event, conducting activities in an integrated manner in promoting innovation within the UN network, printing and dissemination of lab communications materials, participating in global and local meetings and
- Ensure Exploration, Experimentation, and Mapping of local solutions is undertaken-inward (UNDP) and outwardly (innovation ecosystem) scanning of existing local solutions, developing local solution Atlas, Experiment with solutions in urbanisation, agriculture, and the circular economy. Conducting exploration in various parts of Tanzania, Reading weak and strong signals, engaging consultants to support local experiments, assisting COSTECH in taking the lead in 4IR technologies and assisting government with adaptation

In Tanzania, the programme seeks to bring the ‘unusual suspects’ into the development space and promote the use of new sources of data and technologies to address the ever-increasing societal challenges. We seek to add value by; 1) Strengthening legitimacy in the ecosystem; and (2) promoting economic 2) Bringing together people from different sectors of the economy, and 3) elevating new problem solvers by locating and utilizing individual problem solvers in urban and rural settings. The project works in a 100-day cycle modality in running its experiments. The programme’s success is anchored on three components. 1) to inform development programming, 2) to inform government policy, and 3) to spin off lab initiatives into independent ventures.
The first 100-day cycle: (Picking from 2019 plans) The first phase was an exploratory one where the lab focused on three different challenges related to the sectors of 1) agriculture, 2) finance, and 3) urbanization. 1.Agriculture: UNLOCKING THE TANZANIA COMMODITY EXCHANGE MARKET
TMX is the first commodity exchange in Tanzania established and committed to provide a world-class commodity exchange platform for market participants to trade in a wide spectrum of spot and future commodity contracts driven by best global practices, technology, professionalism, and transparency. The Tanzania Mercantile Exchange (TMX) was the first commodity exchange in Tanzania. The exchange was established to help farmers, traders, exporters, and other various market actors access the domestic and global markets and obtain a fair price for selling or buying commodities. Now, the platform is at a pilot stage and has only tested Coffee and Sesame. The ACC lab intervention was aimed at integrating cash crop boards across the country to discuss the viability of posting their crops on the system. All the boards that attended the meeting reached an agreement which indicated their willingness to start using the platform. The acc lab will continue to support TMX in reaching its goal of being the largest commodity trader in Tanzania. This this blog for more info: https://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/blog/strengtheningecommerceinagroculturesector.html
Finance: Rethinking Innovation Financing The lab envisioned engaging various actors in the innovation ecosystem in Tanzania. Local governments, for example, in the Ikungi district in central Tanzania, were supported to devise strategies to finance local innovations through the annual budgeting process. The ACC lab also supported the country office to take the lead in the ongoing talks to establish the first ever multi-stakeholder innovation catalytic fund in Tanzania in collaboration with the DFID funded Human Development and Innovation fund, the EU, Vodacom Tanania, Sahara Ventures, the Swiss Embassy and the Commission for science and technology (COSTECH)-Tanzania. In collaboration with the IG pillar, a project initiation plan has been signed and will be operational through October 2021. The envisaged project, known as the Integrated Innovation Strengthening Programme (IIESP), will provide a catalytic fund for innovation, the strategic innovation platform, and support the government of Tanzania in creating a conducive environment for innovation and also delivering the Tanzania Innovation Facility as an independent entity.
Read more about this initiative on this blog.https://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/blog/investingininnovationandlocalsolutionsthroughlocalbudgetstoachievetheagenda2030alessonfrommsalaladistrictcouncil.html
3: Urbanization: Disrupting Mwanza Citys Solid Waste Management System
Approaching this challenge, the key question was, How can the lab get the city to think of alternative ways to deal with solid waste? After thorough consultations, a design thinking workshop was conducted involving the staff of the Environment and Sanitation department of the City Council of Mwanza, the private sector, academia, and local innovators. The workshop offered the city an opportunity to explore the best options for integrating bankable recycling technologies into the solid waste management systems value chain. After 5 days of discussions, exploratory exercises, solutions safari and prototyping. The city agreed to; 1) create a viable environment for small businesses engaged in recycling by providing guarantees and supporting processes to improve bankability; 2) attract investors in material recovery plant installation and production of compost fertiliser; 3) employ various collective intelligence methods to understand the problem in semi-urban wards, e.g. use of unusual sources of data such as satellite data; 4) encourage learning from successful projects elsewhere; and 4) identify and eliminate bottlenecks in the supply chain 4) run a hackathon to crowdsource ideas that use technology to improve solid waste management systems. 5) convene and elevate local solid waste innovators by building a local innovation forum.
For more information on the initial solid waste work in Mwanza, go to this blog. https://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/blog/solidwastemanagementsystems.html The 2nd 100-day cycle also incorporates COVID19-response. The lab continued to work on the same sectors as mentioned above, but in April it had to re-program to incorporate COVID 19 response after the first patient was identified. The following experiments were conducted during this cycle. • Using satellite imagery to enhance data on solid waste management in Mwanza city • Production of 3D printed clinical masks and respiratory valves to address medical supply shortages (Acc lab in partnership with Robotics Tanzania) • Using Artificial Intelligence to analyze social media posted content to inform COVID-19 messaging by the government (Acc lab in partnership with Xsense AI) • Satellite/Drone imagery for data improvement in SWM
The lab partnered with Open Map Development Tanzania, a non-profit based in Tanzania that uses various GIS technologies to create innovative solutions for various developmental challenges. Furthermore, we engaged volunteer students from Ardhi University. The students’ role in the assignment was to conduct virtual digitization (mapathon)-an approach used due to travel restrictions as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic eruption. The following steps were undertaken; 1) Make a task on the open street map platform www.tasks.hotosm.org to divide the pilot area into squares for mapping.2) Bing and Maxar open imagery sources were used.3)mapped images were reviewed and validated by a GIS expert 4)data was finally uploaded on the OpenStreetMap platform.
See this blog for more information on the project:https://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/blog/Tappiningintoopendataandsateliteimagerytounderstandsolidwasteecosystem.html
Using 3D printing in the fight against COVID 19 The Acc Lab Tanzania partnered with The DIT Design Studio, which is a result of a partnership between DIT and the Rice 360° Institute for Global Health (USA). Usually a site for invention education on the DIT campus, the Design Studio has since turned to innovation to support COVID-19 response efforts. So far, because of this collaboration, the studio has fabricated and distributed over 5000 units of various technologies to support Tanzanian healthcare workers in the fight against the novel coronavirus. The technologies include face shields, intubation boxes and ventilator splitters. This much-needed support has gone to healthcare workers. This impact has reached clinicians at Muhumbili National Hospital, Amana Regional Referral Hospital, Aga Khan Hospital and other regions across Tanzania such as Arusha and Zanzibar. With support from the UNDP, the Design Studio will be able to increase their capacity to respond to coronavirus. This will include distribution of thousands more face shields and testing, fabrication and distribution of intubation boxes, ventilator splitters, medical device spare parts and local sterilization solutions. To ensure maximum production, UNDP Tanzania through the Accelerator Lab programme has also teamed up with Robotech Labs, Bits&Bytes, STIC Labs, Uhuru Labs who are other leaders in the country’s tech space for a unified effort against the novel coronavirus. This this blog for more information: https://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/blog/PPE3DprintingtofightCOVID19inTanzania.html
Using Artificial Intelligence to Tackle online Misinformation related to COVID 19: The case of Kinondoni District. In collaboration with XSense AI (a nonprofit based in Tanzania), the ACC lab investigated social media data to address online misinformation. Unlike other news media, most social media posts are not regulated. This has led to a lot of misinformation. Most of the social media accounts generating misinformation do not share accurate details about themselves. This makes it harder to track them down and act. In addition, although different governments and other organizations were actively providing education on how people could protect themselves against CORONAVIRUS in order to slow down the spread, there was no mechanism to know how well or which parts of the country were not educated for early interventions. In this regard, we checked how well people are educated about CORONAVIRUS by performing sentiment analysis on the posted tweets. We found a relative higher percentage (12.4%) of all tweets related to COVID seemed not educated about the pandemic out of all 2413 COVID related tweets we pulled. This information is useful for related ministries to program COVID related messaging. AI can also be used in various other development interventions.
For more information on this work, click this link. https://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/blog/usingartificialintelligencetotackleinfodemicintanzania.html

-Enhance Communication and Engagement in the Innovation Ecosystem
- Conduct Exploration, Experimentation and Solutions mapping
- Hiring Key Accelerator Labs staff
- Ensure Acc Labs participation in Nationwide Innovation Events

On December 13th, 2019, the UNDP Tanzania Accelerator lab was launched. The colorful ceremony was held on the Msasani peninsula in the CBD of the biggest Tanzanian commercial city, Dar es Salaam. UNDP Tanzania RR Ms. Christine Musisi gave powerful opening remarks on addressing 21st century development challenges. The Acc lab’s core investors, i.e., representatives from the embassy of the Republic of Germany and the chargé daffaires of the Qatar embassy, gave their remarks on separate occasions. The guest of honor was the Director of the Commission on Science and Technology (COSTECH), a government parastatal with a mandate to oversee innovation in the country. The majority of audience members came from the Tanzania innovation ecosystem, including hubs, makerspaces, the private sector, NGOs, and academia, as well as UN agencies and members of the diplomatic corps. This entertaining and exciting event featured speeches, fireside chats, Impact talks, and a local solutions showcase of businesses working in artificial intelligence, block chain, recycling technologies, and robotics.Students from two schools located 5 minutes away from the countrys office were given a challenge to scan their environment, identify challenges, recommend solutions, and present prototypes by using Lego blocks and other materials. In the end, the cocktail party was entertained by Grace Matata, a Tanzanian singing sensation, who also represented youths from the creative industry. Enjoy these pictures from the amazing land of East Africa. Workshops, meet-ups, and engagements The Tanzania accelerator lab selected two challenges; 1) Integration of recycling technologies into solid waste management systems and 2) Agricultural market information for small-holder farmers. To address this challenge, the lab conducted a sequence of activities as shown below: A great deal of sensemaking was done to gather intelligence on the nature and character of the innovation ecosystem in the Mwanza region, a major Tanzanian port on Lake Victoria which borders Uganda to the north and Kenya to the east. By engaging our key client, the city of Mwanza, the team was able to scan the environment to gather information about actors involved in the value chain of the solid waste management system. As a result, the following actors were mapped: Kuni Smart-a social enterprise in rural northern Tanzania making biomass-briquettes by using green waste collected from local markets. 2) MRHP-an award-winning NGO helping spread an innovative solution of making fired clay bricks by using rice-husks instead of traditional firewood/charcoal used as fuel. 3) Sagar Energy-a small company prototyping solar lantern models as an alternative to pressurized kerosene lanterns used by fishermen in Lake Victoria. 4) and lastly, a company making RDL lumber by using recycled plastic. In October 2019, the Tanzania Acc Lab undertook an exploratory visit to Mwanza City. Through the $2.3mn in support by the World Bank’s Tanzania Strategic Cities project https://projects.worldbank.org/en/projects-operations/projectdetail/P111153?lang=en & tab=documents & subTab=projectDocuments The City is turning its major dumpsite into a sanitary landfill by the creation of cells, the construction of inner and access roads, protection works, storm water drains, leachate discharge facilities, and waste collection centers. Through observations by the lab, scavenging activities were predominant. You could almost say that there were no or minimal recycling activities in or around the dumpsite, let alone the region at large. The city’s environment department was enthusiastic about exploring possible ways to integrate recycling technologies inside the landfill. Moving forward, using Design Thinking methodologies, the Lab will facilitate the environment department and recycling stakeholders to prototype possible solutions to bankable circularity businesses, test them and eventually explore options for financing. Exploring possibilities to utilize recycling technologies in SWM by using design thinking methods: The design thinking workshop was conducted with the staff of the Environment and Sanitation department of the City Council of Mwanza (Tanzanias second largest city), the private sector, academia, and local innovators. The workshop offered the city an opportunity to explore the best options for integrating bankable recycling technologies into the solid waste management systems value chain. Highlights from the workshop include: innovative financing mechanisms, collaboration between actors, investment in data and research, and the use of AI. Enjoy the updates from Acc Lab TZ. Next steps: Challenge 1: As a result of the workshop, the following was agreed: • To initiate a multi-stakeholder circular economy forum in Mwanza-The platform will act as a Go To body for issues related to Circular Ec and or SWM. • To present the need of council to establish recycling projects under stakeholder’s collaboration to council standing committees • To provide announced tenders for interested innovation investors in recycling projects-Subject to management approval. • To assess projects, write on recycling for viability. • conduct a study tour to the places where similar recycling projects are implemented. • To create community awareness about solid waste recycling (sorting) of solid waste. • To support innovators to establish recycling projects. • Digitalization of the Solid Waste Management System by: 1) Creating a functional system design solution2) Creation of a beta version of the system3) Enhancement of the systems beta version. 3) System deployment. • 1) Research and preliminary planning for the installation of a composite plant at the landfill 2) Installation of the composite plant • To create community awareness at all levels by January 2020. • to conduct training on solid waste management for innovators, contractors, and entrepreneurs by February 2020. • To orient staff and innovators to learn about integrated solid waste management systems in South Africa and other advanced countries. • To facilitate the exhibition and showcase of solid waste management technologies by December 2019, • to establish a Material Recovery Facility at Buhongwa Sanitary Landfill by June 2021.
Challenge 2: Commodity Exchange Market: After a series of phone calls and physical meetings, the acc lab secured an opportunity to work with the Tanzania Mercantile Exchange to support the integration of cash crops into the trading platform by creating a multi-stakeholder platform to discuss the benefits of using the system. Accelerating usage of Tanzania’s first commodity Exchange Market: TMX is the first commodity exchange in Tanzania established and committed to provide a world-class commodity exchange platform for market participants to trade in a wide spectrum of spot and future commodity contracts driven by best global practices, technology, professionalism and transparency. The Tanzania Mercantile Exchange (TMX) was the first commodity exchange in Tanzania. The exchange was established to help farmers, traders, exporters, and other various market actors access domestic and global markets and obtain a fair price for selling or buying commodities. At the moment, the platform is at a pilot stage and has only tested Coffeee and Sesame. The acc lab intervention is aimed at integrating cash crop boards across the country to discuss the viability of integrating their crops into the system. The meetings board representatives reached an agreement indicating their willingness to begin using the platform.-The acc lab will continue to support TMX in reaching its goal of being the largest commodity trader in Tanzania. Supporting the country office and other innovation ecosystem engagement activities: 1. The lab has been actively involved in developing the joint proposal between UNDP and UNCDF for the UN Joint SDG Fund Call for proposal. The proposal is scheduled to be submitted in March 2020. The first draft of the proposal has been submitted to the Programmes Coordinator and is still waiting for comments and further discussion. The Draft is attached.
2. As part of promoting innovative financing for development, the Lab developed a Concept Note which details how UNDP CO can engage with the President’s Office, Reginal Administration, and Local Governments (PO-RALG) to update and develop frameworks for implementing PPP projects at the local authority level. In addition, the CN detailed areas that UNDP can support PO-RALG to undertake feasibility studies for areas that need to attract more private sector engagements. The CN was approved by the RR and has been shared with the IG pillar for execution. The CN is attached.
3. The lab provided technical support to Msalala Local Government Authority (LGA) as a facilitator for the internal sessions for preparing the annual budget for fiscal year 2020-2021. These mandatory sessions are run in such a way that the councillors and government officials identify the available solutions which can be financed through the local government budget to counter development challenges facing the LGA. The sessions were conducted by following the Acc Lab flow, which means understanding the context of development challenges in the LGA, mapping available local solutions, followed by a detailed workshop and discussions on what can work and what cannot work. The final stage was to integrate (insert) the identified solutions in the draft 2020-2021 budget. The next step is that the lab is working with the Msalala LGA to develop a resource mobilization strategy which will assist the LGA to optimise non-traditional sources of finance for development. The framework which was adopted by the Msalala DC is attached.
4. The Lab has been involved in the exploration of a potential partnership with HDIF to co-convene a Special Purspose Vehicle to finance Innovation in Tanzania. The Commission for Science and Technology, the EU, Denmark, and Finland are among the partners involved, and they are working together to develop a program.At this stage, the two parties have agreed to collaborate in the process of establishing a catalytic fund (beyond the funding of start-ups to incubation, testing, scaling up, etc.). UNDP is offering to host the facility, offering its convening power, back-office support, and its specific role in the partnership of linking innovations to consumers.
Next steps:
• Continue engaging the Mwanza City council in its journey to seek bankable circularity businesses in Mwanza City. • Support the Tanzania Merchantile Exchange to push forward with the crop intergaration and system usage agenda. • To support the country office to completion with the establishment of the Catalytic Fund, an SPV designed to finance innovative businesses in Tanzania, • Support fundraining efforts by CO, e.g., SDG fund call. • The Acc lab will continue with disruptive approaches to influence programming at the local government level, e.g., budgeting processes. • Acc lab Tanzania will assist the Commission for Science and Technology in taking the lead on 4IR technologies such as AI and Block chain. • Organise meet-ups and events to strengthen the Tanzania innovation ecosystem • To contribute to the Big Data and Data Analytics CO workstream by spearheading the establishment of a multi-stakeholder plantform in Tanzania. • Run/support challenge funds/pitching events on ideas worth experimenting with and inline with CO and global workstreams. • Strategic social media activity, posts, and photo and video sharing • Establishment of Tanzania edition of Tedtalk-on 4IR technologies • Management of strategic knowledge • Encourage inter-agency collaboration with the UN family in order to promote innovation. • Strive to achieve 100% cross-pillar support and buy in within the countrys office.

1)Enhanced Communications and local engagement and Acc Labs Exploration, Experimentation and Solutions mapping
2)Acc Labs Exploration, Experimentation and Solutions mapping
